title: Galaxy to slash lithium mining rates amid cash burn
text:
Galaxy Resources has joined the list of battery minerals producers scaling back their mines, revealing that work at its Western Australian lithium mine would reduce by 40 per cent next year.

Galaxy's cutbacks are designed to stem the company's cash burn amid slumping lithium prices, which in the past six months have seen Galaxy's net cash position (including debt) halve to $US137 million ($200 million) from $US285 million.

The plan to cut production at Galaxy's Mt Cattlin mine comes after Pilbara Minerals significantly reduced operations at its Pilgangoora lithium mine in in WA in August, Glencore reduced production of cobalt in Africa in the same month, while in September graphite producer Syrah Resources cut production by 66 per cent.

Even the biggest players in the lithium world are suffering at the moment, with Chinese giant Tianqi, which is half owner of Australia's best lithium mine at Greenbushes, reporting a loss in the three months to September 30.

Galaxy said on Thursday that a review of operations was not complete, but would likely see mining rates at Mt Cattlin in WA reduced by 40 per cent.

The processing of stockpiles should allow Galaxy to produce lithium-rich spodumene concentrate at about 75 per cent of existing rates.
description: Mining rates at Galaxy's Mt Cattlin mine will be reduced 40 per cent next year as the company tries to reduce its cash burn.
